Half-angle formulae

If we replace \(A\) by \(\dfrac{A}{2}\) and, consequently \(2A\) by \(A\), in the double angle formula, we obtain

\(\sin A\equiv 2\sin\left(\dfrac{A}{2}\right)\cos\left(\dfrac{A}{2}\right) \)

Similarly for the cosine:

\(\cos A\equiv 2\cos^2\left(\dfrac{A}{2}\right)-1\)

These are examples of half-angle formulae. We can obtain a half-angle formula for \(\tan A\) as well. Replacing \(A\) by \(\dfrac{A}{2}\) and \(2A\) by \(A\) in the double angle formula for \(\tan\) we obtain:

\(\tan A\equiv \dfrac{2\tan\left(\dfrac{A}{2}\right)}{1-\tan^2\left(\dfrac{A}{2}\right)} \)

Other formulae, which can be obtained using the half-angle formulae and are useful for integration when trigonometric functions are present:


Key Point

If \(t= \tan\left(\dfrac{A}{2}\right)\) then
\(\sin A= \dfrac{2t}{1+t^2}\)
\(\cos A= \dfrac{1-t^2}{1+t^2}\)
\(\tan A= \dfrac{2t}{1-t^2}\)
